title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 10
author: Various
snippet: Edgar, the lawful heir to the English crown, seeingthe country conquered, and the nobles routed and dispersed, tookshipping with his mother and sisters, and arrived in the Frith of Forth,and landed at Queensferry, which received its name from Margaret, theeldest sister of Edgar, whom King Malcolm afterwards married.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 23
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: And we came home fromQueensferry on the outside of the coach and four, along a beautiful wayfull of ups and downs among woody, uneven country, laid out (fifty yearsago, I suppose) by my grandfather, on the notion of Hogarth's line ofbeauty.

title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 23
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: All this beautiful, quiet, sunlitday, I have been out in the country; down by the sea on my favouritecoast between Granton and Queensferry.

title: Stories of the Border Marches

snippet: Mr. Cargill and Ringan Oliver got clear away from thehouse at Queensferry where Colonel Middleton, single-handed, tried toarrest them, but Hall, severely wounded in the head, was taken, and diedbefore he could be carried even so far as Edinburgh.

title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: I reached the Queensferry without, as it were, drawing breath.

title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: The thing, however, most considered at that time was the panic whichthis intemperance would cause to the Queen Regent; and my grandfather,seeing it had changed the complexion of his mission, resolved to returnthe same evening by the Queensferry to the Lord James Stuart atEdinburgh.

title: Ringan Gilhaize, or, The Covenanters
author: Galt, John
snippet: And he counselledthem not to proceed, as my grandfather had proposed, straight on toEdinburgh by the Queensferry, but to hasten up the country to Crieff andthence take the road to Stirling.

title: The antiquary
author: Scott, Walter, Sir
snippet: transport me to Queensferry, agreeably to thy treacherous programme?

title: The antiquary
author: Scott, Walter, Sir
snippet: "We have taken places, ma'am," said the younger stranger, in your diligence for Queensferry." - "Which should have beenhalf-way on the road before now," continued the elder and more impatient traveller, rising in wrath as he spoke; "and now in all likelihood we shall miss the tide, and I have business of importance on the other side - and your cursed coach-"

title: The antiquary
author: Scott, Walter, Sir
snippet: It was early on a fine summer's day, near the end of the eighteenth century, when a young man, of genteel appearance journeying towards the north-east of Scotland, provided himself with a ticket in one of those public carriages which travel between Edinburgh and the Queensferry, at which place, as the name implies, and is is well known to all my northern readers, there is a passage-boat for crossing the Frith of Forth.

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: At a place called Queensferry, so named because  Queen Margaret used to land there when on her way from Edinburgh to her abbey of Dunfermline, their train began the crossing of the famous Forth Bridge over the great bay called the Firth of Forth.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Queensferry  is 2259 feet above the level of the sea.

title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: All day we kept moving, though often not much more j and it was after dark ere we were up with the Queensferry.

title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: I learned long afterwards that she had despatched a horseman by daylight to Eankeillor at the Queensferry, whom she knew to be the doer for Shaws, and had then in her pocket a letter from that good friend of mine, presenting, in the most favourable view, my character and prospects.

title: [Works]

snippet: I told him I was come to the Queensferry on business, and taking heart of grace, asked him to direct me to the house of Mr. Eankeillor.

snippet: The town of Queensferry lies farther west, and the neighbourhood of the inn looked pretty lonely at that time of day, for the boat had just gone north with passengers.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: We went on horseback by Queensferry, Perth, Dundee, Arbroath, &c. We stayed four days and nights at Aberdeen on account of Dr Wight's horse having been lamed in crossing the ferry at Montrose ; but we passed our time very agreeably between the houses of our friends Drs Campbell and Gerard.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: He returned to Edinburgh by Kinross and Queensferry,  and while at Dunfermline some circumstances took place, trivial in themselves, but important as exhibiting what rapid changes took place in the weather of the poet's mind.

snippet: " By the way, Father, have you still the same tuftof rusty hair you showed me at the Queensferry ?If its virtue is not exhausted, surely it should havefound you a better place than this wherein to layyour head."

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: Being ignorant ofthe country, he did not know that the AlmondWater, before passing under the bridge at Cramond,ran for a considerable distance close to the southside of the road he had followed from Queensferry.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: Travellers indeed from the Queensferry to Perthwould sometimes break their journey at Kinross andfurnish employment for a few horseboys; but theplace had no other excuse for existence, except theneeds of Douglas of Lochleven and other owners ofthe land in the neighbourhood.
